item.title: Natural Transformation
item.description: Motivation & Definition Definition. Let $F,G:C\to D$ be covariant functors between categories $C$ and $D$. A natural transformation $\eta:F\to G$ is a function assigning to each $c\in C$ a morphism $\eta_c:Fc\to Gc$ of $D$ such that for every $f:c\to c’$, the diagram

item.title: Functor
item.description: Motivation & Definition Definition. Let $C$ and $D$ be categories. A (covariant) functor $F:C\to D$ is the data of two functions: An object function, assigning some $Fc\in D$ to each $c\in C$, and A morphism function, assigning some $Ff:Fc\to Fc’$ to each $f:c\to c’$, interacting in such a way that $$\begin{equation} F1_c=1_{Fc}\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \textrm{and}\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ F(f\circ g)=Ff\circ Fg \end{equation}$$ for all objects $c\in C$ and morphisms $f,g\in C$ whenever $f\circ g\in C$ is defined.

item.title: Category
item.description: Motivation & Definition The starting point of the theory of categories is the observation that many properties of mathematical objects can be more succinctly expressed as diagrams of arrows $-$ as opposed to an equation $-$ and that many objects can be constructed via a ‘universal property’ of such a diagram; heuristically then, these objects are characterized as the ‘most efficient solution to a certain optimization problem’. To formalize this, we need a general framework for composing arrows, so we make the following

item.title: Group Action
item.description: Motivation & Definition Groups capture $-$ abstractly $-$ the notion of a symmetry. But symmetries are also present in concrete objects, with different kinds of objects preserving different kinds of structure. The concept of a group action connects the two. Definition. Let $G$ be a group and fix a category $C$. A $G$-action is a functor $\cat{B}G\to C$, which specifies an object $X\in C$ and a homomorphism $\phi:G\to\Aut X$. Thus a group action is specified by the data of a tuple $\tpl{X,\phi}$, which we usually write as $\phi:G\act X$.

item.title: Abelian Group
item.description: Here, we consider a class of groups which $-$ despite being very general $-$ exhibit very useful properties absent in general groups. Definition. A group $G$ is said to be Abelian if $gh=hg$ for all $g,h\in G$. We denote the subcategory of Abelian groups as $\catabgrp$, which is one of the most well-behaved categories. Indeed, ???. We have a forgetful functor $\catmod[\Z]\to\catabgrp$, which is an isomorphism of categories ???. In this way, the notions of torsion, rank, etc, all carry forward.

item.title: Group
item.description: Motivation & Definition The concept of a group was invented to capture the abstract properties of symmetries (i.e. transformations that preserve internal ‘structure’) of geometrical objects. These transformations must be composable in the following coherent way. Definition. A group is a tuple $\tpl{G,\cdot,e,\iota}$ consisting of underlying set $G$, a distinguished element $e\in G$ called the identity, and operations $\cdot:G\times G\to G$ and $\iota:G\to G$, subject to the following conditions. (Associativity). For all $g,h,k\in G$, we have $g\cdot(h\cdot k)=(g\cdot h)\cdot k$.

item.title: Metric Space
item.description: Motivation & Definition Abstracting away the basic properties of Euclidean distance in $\R^n$, and most notably preserving the Triangle Inequality, we make the following Definition. A metric on a set $X$ is a function $d:X\times X\to\R_{\geq0}$ such that (Positive-definiteness). For all $x,y\in X$, we have $d(x,y)=0$ iff $x=y$. (Symmetry.) For all $x,y\in X$, we have $d(x,y)=d(y,x)$. ($\Delta$-inequality). For all $x,y,z\in X$, we have $d(x,z)\leq d(x,y)+d(y,z)$. If $d$ is a metric on $X$, we call the pair $\tpl{X,d}$ a metric space.

item.title: Topological Space
item.description: Motivation & Definition Let $X$ be a set. We would like to formalize a notion of ‘closeness’ between two points without necessarily referring to a specific metric, but rather, via certain subsets of $X$ called open sets. The following definition is motivated by some properties $^\dagger$ of open sets generated by a metric $d$ on $X$, which we now axiomatize. Definition. Let $X$ be a set. A topology on $X$ is a family $\mc{O}_X\subseteq\pow(X)$, whose elements are called open sets, subject to the following conditions.
